I absolutely agree the inability to crouch on scaffolding makes it so much harder to use for literally it's main purpose.

I think your suggestion is a neat solution that only adds a feature and has no drawbacks.
One thing came to my notice when I was working with scaffolding. If you only had one scaffolding with no blocks underneath, you can enter sneak mode and crouch without falling.
I was going to suggest something much more convoluted. This is way better.

It's pretty hard to leave behind something you have worked on for a few years just to be forced to explore far from your base to even find the updated areas. Then you realize that the more you explore the harder it will be to explore in the next update because even though you just looked at a few random spots and did nothing of importance in them they will never again be updated. 

It is really annoying that just because you loaded a chunk and never did anything important in it that now that chunk will never be updated. Then on top of that random chunks will and won't update making your world look like throw up because random chunks decided to not update making them super tall or low compared to the surrounding area. 

Basically, this is a good idea and should be added. Also, if there is ever a cave update you should be able to select whether or not you want to update the underground area and select the axis level at which your world will update below it. So basically if my base goes 20 blocks underground I select the Y axis at which my base ends so all the blocks under that throughout my world will be updated.

This is sooo needed for PS4. I have been playing my survival world for over a year and have countless hours of building into it.

New village and pillage update come out and I have to fly around for hundreds or thousands of blocks to find a new type village. I have explored hundreds of chunks to find Mesa biome which will never be updated.

With the new nether update I‚Äôm also disappointed because I won‚Äôt see the new biomes due to exploration.

Deleting chunks is possible on java and I feel like PS4 players are punished for exploring their worlds and putting time into creating/building their worlds.

This sounds impossible, even if it is possible it would be way too difficult. I don't know much of what I talk about in this regard, but to my understanding the save files would have to be updated. Updating new chunks individually would make the grounds uneven and you would have to update every single chunk you generated.

I think I agree, possibly you could check whether the player has really placed any important blocks, e.g. planks, crafting table, chest, and then update it and blend it. But if that doesn‚Äôt work, maybe we could have a way to see which chucks have been explored.
Do you mean java combat on bedrock? As someone who doesn't play the newer versions of minecraft BECAUSE of the newer combat I would suggest against this.
TrulyTails the java combat is the newer and better one. Move on.

I think there should be a potion, not an enchantment, that does this.  Otherwise, I agree.

@Bilbo Baggins I thought an enchantment would have more sense just because an armore gives the idea of something that could be potentially magnetic. I really like the idea of the potion, but in that case I might want to change the name.
I gotta say I agreed with @Bilbo Baggins it should be a potion

I think I like the enchantment idea. Though, one step further could be it works on where you're looking? So let's say max level you could look at a distance and exp would come to you, or an item you left at a distance, or killed something with a bow.

I'll suggest it as a enchantment but for the gloves (armor hand), althrough it isn't included this could fit perfectly for that.

1.An Enchantmet to attract an specific type of item.

2.This enchantment could help you in a very nice way how tou maybe be wondering, when you're using a tool or a mob drops a tool if it is a metal one no matter is an item if it is made of a metallic material you can attract it to you.

3. This would work on the next way:
Each level the distance is increased by +3 per level starting with +5 block distance on the level 1.
When you attract an item it can travel through any type of block, liquid.(this means this item can travel trough lava without getting burned)
Increase of the speed of +0.4 block/sec per level starting with a speed of +1 block/sec on level 1.
When you're attracting an item it reduces the durability of it based on the distance -1 durability per 5 blocks of distance.
For both version you need to point the item wich you want and then on bedrock press the attract button and on java press the attrack button. (Only if you have the gloves and you're not using any weapon, tool, item, block. on your hand)

I think since it will be really useful it should also come with the downside that mob (and player) projectiles (arrows, tridents, snowballs, wither black and blue skulls, and fireballs) will come to you much faster.

Was just about to post this same idea. The chestplate has no unique enchantments atm so it would be great to add one and this is the perfect fit. It would be a nice quality of life feature too. I wouldn't necessarily call it magnetism though, as it should work for all dropped items (in a similar way to how XP orbs currently are attracted to you), not just metal (and Minecraft isn't and shouldn't be grounded in any realworld physics)
Um... they already do

Considering it is an accessibility feature and Microsoft/Xbox claim to be accessibility friendly this 100% needs to be implemented.

• Most sold game all time (350+ million copies)
  • Owned by trillion $ company
  • Game is 15+ years old
  • No Toggle Sneak when sneak is mandatory 
  • NO BORDERLESS FULLSCREEN?!
  • Has NO Sorting Options (practically every crafting/build/rpg game has that)

Bedrock's issues are indictive of a larger root problem of Mojang.
Mojang, if you even happen to stumble upon this *Suggestion*, please concentrate some resources on better QOL options.

The range should actually be about 6 blocks since the length of a block in minecraft is a meter and 20 feet is equal to 6.096 meters. This would still be rather useful in effectively allowing pistons to pull different blocks separated by chains out at different distances. We would need to add bunched or coiled chains to the game to account for the pushing action of pistons as well as what happens vertically if the top of a chain is let go of or given slack. Ideally a pulley could also be added to allow changes in the direction of a single chain which would open up some new applications for this possible new mechanic.
Making all blocks entities would crash the game and severely decrease preformance :/
One block is ~3 feet so 6 blocks would actually make the most sense
There are add-ons instead. Also, there's a big issue with this. There would be no way to add mods to consoles without hacking and likely violating the warranty.
